results.headline: Lonely Boy Finds Friend in Blood-Craving Pixie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let Me In

results.summary_short: In the vampire romance “Let Me In,” Matt Reeves tells a tale not about sex but rather about the fragility and loneliness of children.

results.headline: Three Men Behaving (Really) Badly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speed-Dating

results.summary_short: In “Speed-Dating,” a mash-up of men-behaving-badly sitcoms, three friends try to save a nightclub while refreshing their hookup pool.

results.headline: Shots From the Underground

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of S&Man

results.summary_short: “S&Man” glimpses three of the more extreme makers of underground horror and fetish films.

results.headline: Tribulations of a Gay Priest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Release

results.summary_short: “Release,” a bleak prison drama, recounts the tribulations of an incarcerated gay priest.

results.headline: Liberté in a Lover’s Embrace

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leaving

results.summary_short: Kristin Scott Thomas and Sergi López embark on a dangerous affair in the French drama “Leaving,” directed by Catherine Corsini.

results.headline: A Romance of Mistaken Identity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Is It Just Me?

results.summary_short: “Is It Just Me?,” a mistaken-identity romance, upends perceptions of the gay dating scene.

results.headline: Mastering Martial Arts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ip Man

results.summary_short: “Ip Man,” a proletarian kung fu movie by Wilson Yip, tells the life story of a Chinese martial arts master.

results.headline: Eastern Religion in an Ensemble Drama

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hungry Ghosts

results.summary_short: Michael Imperioli’s “Hungry Ghosts” is an ensemble drama that applies the “Crash” formula to New York.

results.headline: Intertwining Love and Obsession

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Summer Days

results.summary_short: In “Hot Summer Days,” several loosely intertwined stories explore love and obsession.

results.headline: An Homage to Slasher-Movie History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hatchet II

results.summary_short: In “Hatchet II,” a swamp-dwelling mutant resumes his murderous vendetta.

results.headline: A Best Seller as 4 Films Tied Together With Talk

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Freakonomics

results.summary_short: “Freakonomics” uses different directors for each of its segments about subject matter from the book “Freakonomics: a Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything.”

results.headline: Two Brothers on the Road, and One’s Bad Company

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Douchebag

results.summary_short: In a road movie in search of something or someone, two brothers find nothing interesting to say.

results.headline: Students Caught in the School Squeeze

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waiting for 'Superman'

results.summary_short: A powerful and alarming documentary about America’s failing public school system.

results.headline: A Fight to Preserve Tibetan Music

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tibet in Song

results.summary_short: “Tibet in Song” tells of an exile struggling with the Chinese to preserve the traditional music of his people.

results.headline: Millions of Friends, but Not Very Popular

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Social Network

results.summary_short: David Fincher’s film is less of a biopic of the Facebook co-founder than a gloss on the boot-up, log-on, plug-in generation.

results.headline: Altering Perceptions on an Astral Plane Trip

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enter the Void

results.summary_short: Gaspar Noé’s “Enter the Void” takes viewers on a trippy out-of-body flight above Tokyo through the point of view of a drug dealer who is dead — or dreaming.

results.headline: It’s a Mean-Girl World: Are You Bully or Victim?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Again

results.summary_short: “You Again,” with Kristen Bell, Sigourney Weaver and Jamie Lee Curtis, is a misogynistic revenge comedy.

results.headline: The Pride That Went Before the Fall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps

results.summary_short: In Oliver Stone’s film, Gordon Gekko returns as a villain who is more charismatic than the good guys.

results.headline: Confronting Autism
results.display_title: A Mother's Courage: Talking Back to Autism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Mother's Courage: Talking Back to Autism

results.summary_short: “A Mother’s Courage” tracks a woman’s search for help for her autistic son.

results.headline: Adoption Struggles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Like Dandelion Dust

results.summary_short: “Like Dandelion Dust” revisits the pain of a tug of war over an adopted child.
